fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y in a category is an isomorphism if there exists an inverse morphism y\xrightarrow {f^{-1}}x such that f^{-1}f = 1_x and ff^{-1} = 1_y, i.e.
and
commute. If there exists an isomorphism between x and y, we say they are isomorphic and write x\cong y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

A homotopical category is a category equipped with a collection of morphisms W, called the weak equivalences, which contains the isomorphisms and satisfies the two-of-six property (hence is closed under composition and so forms a wide subcategory). A homotopical functor is a functor which preserves weak equivalences; the category of homotopical categories is so defined.
The isomorphisms in any category satisfy the two-of-six property, hence form the minimal homotopical structure on that category.
A class of morphisms S is saturated if it creates isomorphisms under localization C\xrightarrow {Q} C[S^{-1}].
A preabelian category is abelian if every morphism is strict, i.e. if the natural map from its coimage to its image is an isomorphism.

Let x\xrightarrow {f} y be a map in a category with zero. Then the image of f is isomorphic to the kernel of the cokernel of f. Dually, the coimage of f is isomorphic to the cokernel of the kernel of f.
A map x\xrightarrow {f} y, say in a complete and cocomplete category, is strict if the comparison map from its coimage to its image is an isomorphism.

Since \mathbb {Z} is the initial ring, there is a unique ring homomorphism from \mathbb {Z} to \operatorname {End}(A) for any abelian group A. This defines an isomorphism of categories Ab \cong \mathbb {Z}Mod.

Let G be a group and N\unlhd G. Then there is a lattice isomorphism between the lattice of subgroups of G containing N and the lattice of subgroups of the quotient G/N, which sends N\leq A\leq G to A/N. Moreover, this assignment preserves and reflects normality.
Let G\xrightarrow {\varphi } H be a group homomorphism. Then there is an isomorphism G/\ker (\varphi ) \cong \operatorname {im}(\varphi ). of the quotient of the kernel and the image.
Grp is regular; this is the statement of (regular epi, mono) factorization.

fr:title.text: The counit of the nerve adjunction is an isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The counit of the nerve adjunction is an isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Because the nerve functor is fully faithful, the counit of the adjunction between the nerve and homotopy category is an isomorphism h(N(C))\cong C.
The topology generated by K is the Grothendieck topology wherein a sieve S covers an object x if and only if T\subseteq S for some T\in K(x).
A bicartesian category C is distributive if the canonical comparison morphism (A\times B) + (A\times C)\to A\times (B+C) is an isomorphism.

fr:title.text: Subobject classifiers are unique up to isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobject classifiers are unique up to isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Subobject classifiers are unique up to isomorphism.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Subobject classifiers represent the subobject functor and representations are unique.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category is skeletal if, whenever two objects are isomorphic, they are equal.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is conservative if it reflects isomorphisms, i.e. if for any map x\xrightarrow {f} y in C, if F(f) is an isomorphism, then so is f.

fr:title.text: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let x\xrightarrow {f} x be an idempotent isomorphism. Then f = 1_x.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We have f = f1_x = fff^{-1} = ff^{-1} = 1_x.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor so that, for each object d\in D, there exists a cofree object Gd\in C, i.e. an object Gd\in C together with an isomorphism {D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd)} natural in D. Then there exists a unique extension of this assignment into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C, which is then necessarily right adjoint to F.
Dually, suppose that for each d\in D, there exists a free object Fd\in C. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C which is necessarily left adjoint to F.
Let F: C\leftrightarrows D: G be a pair of opposing functors. Then the following are equivalent specifications of an adjunction:

fr:ul.fr:li: there exists a natural bijection D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd);
there exists a pair of natural transformations 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF and FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D satisfying the triangle identities;

there exists a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D so that the formula for adjoint maps induces an isomorphism (-)^\sharp = C(c, Gd)\xrightarrow {F} D(Fc, FGd)\xrightarrow {(\epsilon _d)_*} D(Fc, d).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first implies the second via the triangle identities of the unit and counit.

fr:title.text: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the forwards direction, suppose that the isomorphisms are natural, and further that the left-hand square commutes; the case in which the right-hand square commutes is similar. By the naturality of the isomorphism in C, the transpose of kf^\sharp is (Gk) f^\flat , while by naturality in D, the transpose of (Fh)g^\sharp is hg^\flat . Since the maps are equal, their transposes must also be equal; this is commutativity of the square on the right.
Let J\xrightarrow {F,G} C be naturally isomorphic diagrams. Then if their limits exist, they are isomorphic.
Taking limits is functorial and functors preserve isomorphism.

Let I\times J\xrightarrow {F} C be a bifunctorial diagram such that the limits \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F and \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F exist. Then \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F exists, and the three limits are isomorphic.

Since representable isomorphism implies isomorphism, it suffices to prove that C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F) naturally in X. Since hom functors preserve limits, the desired result becomes \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I C(X, F); i.e., the general case reduces to that of Set. By the isomorphism I\times J\cong J\times I, it suffices to prove the first isomorphism.

The proof is essentially by currying. Let I\times J\xrightarrow {G} Set be a diagram. By the construction of limits in Set, the limit \operatorname *{lim}_J G(i, -) is the set of cones over G(i, -) with summit *, hence equivalently the set of J-tuples (x_j\in G(i, j)) satisfying G(i, f)(x_j) = x_{j'} for each j\xrightarrow {f}j'\in J. Taking the limit over I, we now conclude that \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J G consists of the tuples (x_{ij}\in G(i, j)) which commute with G-images of maps in I and J. This is exactly the data of \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} G.

fr:title.text: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cones. Explicitly, let J\xrightarrow {d} C be a diagram and suppose x\xrightarrow {\lambda } D and y\xrightarrow {\mu } D are both limiting cones. Then there is a unique isomorphism x\to y commuting with the \lambda and \mu .
Dually, colimits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cocones.

This follows from the characterization of representable isomorphism, but we give a direct proof. To show isomorphism, note that the universal property of limits induces a pair of unique maps x\xtofrom [g]{f} y commuting with the cones; it remains to show these are isomorphisms. The composite gf is a map x\to x commuting with the cone \lambda , but 1_x is another such map, so by uniqueness of suchs maps gf = 1_x. The same works on the other side.
Fully faithful functors reflect isomorphisms.
Explicitly, let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a full and faithful functor. Then if x\xrightarrow {f} y in C is such that Ff is an isomorphism, then f is an isomorphism.

Let g be the inverse of Ff. Since F is full, there exists an f^{-1} in C such that Ff^{-1} = g. Now, F(f^{-1}f) = Ff^{-1}Ff = 1_{Fx} = F1_x,and the same on the other side, which completes the proof by faithfulness of F.
Fully faithful functors create isomorphisms.
Explicitly, let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a full and faithful functor. Then x\cong y in C if and only if Fx\cong Fy in D.
In the forwards direction, we already know that functors preserve isomorphisms.

Let Fx\xrightarrow {g} Fy be an isomorphism in D. Since F is full, there is a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y in C such that Ff = g. Now the result follows because fully faithful functors reflect isomorphisms.
Let x and y be objects in a category C. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ul.fr:li: the covariant hom-functors C(x, -) and C(y, -) are naturally isomorphic;
the contravariant hom-functors C(-, x) and C(-, y) are naturally isomorphic.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Furthermore, by the Yoneda embedding, a choice of any such isomorphism canonically determines a choice of each of the others.
This is immediate from the Yoneda lemma, since fully faithful functors create isomorphism.
We prove the covariant case. The forwards result comes from functoriality of the Yoneda embedding and the fact that functors preserve isomorphism.

In the backward direction, let \eta : C(x, -)\to C(y, -) be a natural isomorphism. Define t = \eta _x(1_x), which is a morphism y\to x, and u = \eta _y^{-1}(1_y), which is a morphism x\to y. We claim these are inverses.
When we say "the" X, we sometimes mean the unique X up to coherent or canonical isomorphism.

Let c and d be objects in a category C, and suppose that F and x express universal properties of both c and d. Then there is a canonical isomorphism c\cong d; in particular, a unique isomorphism that commutes with the corresponding representations.
We are thus justified in referring to "the universal object with an x."

Let C(c, -)\overset {\alpha _x}{\cong } F and C(d, -)\overset {\beta _x}{\cong } F be the corresponding natural isomorphisms given by definition of a universal property. Then their composition gives an isomorphism C(c, -)\cong C(d, -), which lifts to an isomorphism c\cong d by the Yoneda lemma.
A bijection is an isomorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map is bijective if it is both injective and surjective.
Functors preserve isomorphisms.
Explicitly, let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor. If x\xrightarrow {f} y is an isomorphism in C, then Ff is an isomorphism in D.
The inverse is Ff^{-1}. We have (Ff^{-1})(Ff) = F(f^{-1}f) = F(1_x) = 1_{F(x)}, and the same works on the other side.
A groupoid is a category whose morphisms are each isomorphisms.
A homeomorphism is an isomorphism in Top. Explicitly, it is a continuous bijection with continuous inverse.
A natural isomorphism is an isomorphism in a functor category. Explicitly, it is a natural transformation whose components are each isomorphisms.
A morphism is an automorphism if it is both an endomorphism and an isomorphism.
Let x\xrightarrow {f}y be an isomorphism with inverses g and h. Then g = h.
We have g = g1_y = gfh = 1_xh = h.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
